{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Vivek Kundra |image = Vivek-kundra-2.jpg |office = 1st [[Chief Information Officer of the United States]] |president = [[Barack Obama]] |predecessor = [[Karen S. Evans|Karen Evans]] (Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government and Information Technology) |successor = [[Steven VanRoekel]] |term_start = March 5, 2009 |term_end = August 4, 2011 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|10|9}} |birth_place = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] |nationality = American |death_date = |death_place = |alma_mater = [[University of Maryland, College Park]]
[[University of Maryland University College|University of Maryland, University College]] }} '''Vivek Kundra''' (born October 9, 1974) is an [[United States|American]] administrator who served as the first [[chief information officer of the United States]] from March, 2009 to August, 2011 under President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/President-Obama-Names-Vivek-Kundra-Chief-Information-Officer/|title=President Obama Names Vivek Kundra Chief Information Officer|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2009-03-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306072025/https://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/President-Obama-Names-Vivek-Kundra-Chief-Information-Officer/|archive-date=2009-03-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} He is currently the Chief Operating Officer at Sprinklr and a visiting [[Fellow]] at [[Harvard University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/06/16/our-nation-s-first-federal-cio/|title=Our Nation's First Federal CIO|work=whitehouse.gov}} He previously served in [[Mayor of the District of Columbia|D.C. Mayor]] [[Adrian Fenty]]'s cabinet as the District's Chief Technology Officer and in [[Governor of Virginia|Virginia Governor]] [[Tim Kaine]]'s cabinet as Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Technology. == Early life and education == Kundra was born in [[New Delhi]], [[India]], on October 9, 1974. He moved to [[Tanzania]] with his family at the age of one, when his father joined a group of professors and teachers to provide education to local residents. Kundra learned [[Swahili language|Swahili]] as his first language, in addition to [[Hindi]] and English. His family moved to the [[Washington, D.C.]] metropolitan area when he was eleven.{{cite journal |author = Hart, Kim |date = 2009-01-04 |title = D.C.'s Kinetic Tech Czar |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/04/AR2009010401235_3.html |publisher = Washington Post |accessdate = 2009-03-05 }}Sorensen Institute for Political Leadership [http://www.sorenseninstitute.org/newsroom/entry/political-leaders-2007-profile-vivek-kundra "Political Leaders 2007 Profile: Vivek Kundra"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208172151/http://sorenseninstitute.org/newsroom/entry/political-leaders-2007-profile-vivek-kundra |date=2009-02-08 }}, University of Virginia Kundra attended college at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]] where he received a [[Bachelor of Science|degree]] in Psychology. He earned a [[Master of Science|master's degree]] in Information Technology, from [[University of Maryland University College]]. Additionally, he is a graduate of the [[University of Virginia]]'s [[Sorensen Institute for Political Leadership]].{{cite journal |author = Gourley, Bob |date = 2009-02-03 |title = Vivek Kundra: The Alpha CTO |url = http://ctovision.com/2009/02/vivek-kundra-the-alpha-cto |publisher = CTOVision.com |accessdate = 2009-11-09 }} == Career == Kundra served as director of Infrastructure Technology for [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington County]], Virginia, starting September 11, 2001. Governor [[Tim Kaine]] appointed Kundra in January 2006 to the post of Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Technology for Virginia, the first dual cabinet role in the state's history. Mayor Adrian Fenty appointed him on March 27, 2007 to the cabinet post of Chief Technology Officer (CTO) for the [[District of Columbia]]. Kundra worked on developing programs to spur [[open source]] and [[crowdsourced]] applications using publicly accessible Web services from the District of Columbia. Building on the work of Suzanne Peck, who preceded him as DC's CTO and created the [http://data.octo.dc.gov/ D.C. Data Catalog],{{cite web|url=http://www.infoworld.com/d/developer-world/open-government-meets-it-161|title=Open government meets IT|author=Jon Udell|date=28 June 2006|work=InfoWorld}} he used that data as the source material for an initiative called [http://www.appsfordemocracy.org/ Apps for Democracy]. The contest yielded 47 web, iPhone and Facebook applications from residents in 30 days. Mayor Fenty stated that the program cost the District "50 thousand dollars total and we estimate that we will save the district millions of dollars in program development costs".{{cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/gt/articles/559929|title=47 Applications in 30 Days for $50K|publisher=}} This cost-benefit was claimed by the D.C. government as savings in internal operational and contractual costs.http://www.appsfordemocracy.org/ Taking a page from KundraNational Journal (06-29-2009)[http://techdailydose.nationaljournal.com/2009/06/bloomberg-unveils-govt-apps-co.php "Bloomberg Unveils Gov't Apps Contest"] this initiative was mirrored by [[New York City]]'s mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] in launching a "BigApps" contest housed at [[New York City BigApps|NYC BigApps]] as well as New York City's DataMine.New York Future Initiative (06-29-2009)[http://nyfi.observer.com/politics/208/pdf-bloomberg-announces-big-apps-contest-says-dine-winner "Bloomberg Announces 'Big Apps' Contest"] The city of San Francisco launched a data portal similar DC's in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/pcio/San-Franciscos-DataSForg-Wont-be-a.html|title=San Francisco|publisher=}} Kundra won recognition for the project management system he implemented for the District government.{{cite web|url=http://www.infoworld.com/d/adventures-in-it/2008-infoworld-cto-25-vivek-kundra-district-columbia-048|title=2008 InfoWorld CTO 25: Vivek Kundra, District of Columbia|author=Galen Gruman|date=2 June 2008|work=InfoWorld}}http://www.mitcio.com/2008/ The system imagined projects as publicly traded companies, project schedules as quarterly reports, and user satisfaction as stock prices. Buying or selling a stock corresponded to adding resources to a project or taking them away. The goal of management was to optimize the project portfolio for return on investment. The system effectively replaced subjective judgments about projects with objective, data driven analytics. Kundra's efforts to use [[Cloud computing|cloud-based]] web applications in the D.C. government have also been considered innovative.http://www.gcn.com/print/27_28/47565-1.html Following the D.C. example driven by Kundra, the city of Los Angeles is now taking steps to adopt the cloud computing model for its IT needs.news.cnet.com (08-20-2009)[http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-10313846-245.html "Los Angeles gets its Google Apps groove"] A D.C. spokeswoman said that the District of Columbia paid $479,560 for the Enterprise [[Google Apps]] license, which is $3.5 million less than what it had planned to spend on an alternative plan. Since its deployment in July 2008 Google Apps is available to 38,000 D.C. city employees, but only 1,000–2,000 are actively using Google Docs. Only 200 employees are actively using Gmail.{{cite web|last=Perez|first=Juan Carlos|title=Despite Predictions to the Contrary, Exchange Holds off Gmail in D.C. |url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/251920/despite_predictions_to_the_contrary_exchange_holds_off_gmail_in_dc.html|publisher=IDG News|accessdate=15 March 2012}} In late 2010, hoping to spur use of [[Gmail]], the city ran a pilot program, selecting about 300 users and having them use the Google product for three months. Google participated closely in the project, but Gmail ultimately didn't pass the "as good or better" test with the users, who preferred Exchange/Outlook. In July 2011, the [[General Services Administration]] (GSA) became the first federal agency to migrate its email services for 17,000 employees and contractors to the cloud-based Google Apps for Government, saving $15.2 million over 5 years.{{cite web|url=http://gsablogs.gsa.gov/gsablog/2011/07/26/gsa-is-in-the-cloud/|title=GSA is in the Cloud|work=The GSA Blog}} As of July 2011, government agencies in 42 states are leveraging cloud-based messaging and collaboration services.{{cite web|url=http://googleenterprise.blogspot.com/2011/07/google-apps-for-government-turns-one.html|title=Official Google for Work Blog: Google Apps for Government turns one!|work=Official Google for Work Blog}} Kundra also moved the city's [[geographic information systems]] department to a middle school.{{cite web|url=http://vivekkundra.blogspot.com/2007_11_01_archive.html|title=CTO's Blog: November 2007|author=Vivek Kundra|publisher=}} ===Federal Chief Information Officer (CIO) === Before his appointment as CIO, Mr. Kundra served as technology adviser on President Barack Obama's transition team. Kundra was officially named by President Obama on March 5, 2009, to the post of Federal CIO.{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/06/16/our-nation-s-first-federal-cio|title=JUNE 16, 2011 AT 9:13 AM ET BY JACK LEW}} The Federal Chief Information Officer is responsible for directing the policy and strategic planning of federal information technology investments as well as for oversight of federal technology spending. Until Kundra, the position had previously been more limited within the [[Office of Management and Budget]] where a federal chief information officer role had been created by the [[E-Government Act of 2002]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-107publ347/html/PLAW-107publ347.htm|title="E-Government Act 2002"|publisher=}} The Federal CIO establishes and oversees enterprise architecture to ensure system interoperability and information sharing and maintains information security and privacy across the federal government. According to President Obama, as Chief Information Officer, Kundra "will play a key role in making sure our government is running in the most secure, open, and efficient way possible". To further President Obama's overall technology agenda, Vivek Kundra, [[Jeffrey Zients]], the Chief Performance Officer, and [[Aneesh Chopra]], the Chief Technology Officer, will work closely together.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Weekly-Address-President-Obama-Discusses-Efforts-to-Reform-Spending/|title=Weekly Address: President Obama Discusses Efforts to Reform Spending, Government Waste; Names Chief Performance Officer and Chief Technology Officer|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2009-05-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507200048/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Weekly-Address-President-Obama-Discusses-Efforts-to-Reform-Spending/|archive-date=2009-05-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} Kundra and Chopra previously worked in Governor Tim Kaine's administration.{{cite web|url=http://www.governor.virginia.gov/MediaRelations/newsReleases/viewRelease.cfm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007171536/http://www.governor.virginia.gov/MediaRelations/NewsReleases/viewRelease.cfm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|archivedate=October 7, 2008 |publisher=}} Kundra made it a priority to focus on the following areas: * Cybersecurity * Ensuring openness and transparency * Innovation{{cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/gt/653151|title=Vivek Kundra, Federal CIO, Addresses State CIOs|publisher=}} * Lowering the cost of government * Participatory democracy One of his first projects was the launch of [[Data.gov]], a site for access to raw government data.{{cite web|url=http://radar.oreilly.com/2009/03/vivek-kundra-federal-cio-in-hi.html|title=Vivek Kundra: Federal CIO in His Own Words|author=Timothy M. O'Brien|publisher=}} Another project launched by Kundra in June 2009 was the Federal IT Dashboard, which gives an assessment (in terms of cost, schedule and CIO ranking) of many large government IT projects.http://www.govtech.com/gt/698705?topic=290182 ====Democratizing Data==== Kundra launched the Data.gov platform on May 21, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/blog/globespotting/archives/2009/12/the_power_of_go.html |title=The Power of Government-as-Platform|accessdate=2010-02-13 |last=Hamm |first=Steve |date=2009-12-01 |work=Business Week }} with the goal of providing public access to raw datasets generated by the Executive Branch of the Federal Government to enable public participation and private sector innovation.{{cite web|url=http://data.gov | title=Data.gov |accessdate=2010-02-13 }} Data.gov draws conceptual parallels from the DC Data Catalog launched by Kundra when he was CTO of Washington, D.C., where he published vast amounts of datasets for public use. Immediately after the Data.gov launch, the Apps for America{{cite web|url=http://gcn.com/articles/2009/04/24/sunlight.aspx |title=Sunlight Foundation reveals winners in its Apps for America contest|accessdate=2010-02-13 |last=Jackson |first=Joab |date=2009-04-24 |work=Government Computer News}} contest by the [[Sunlight Foundation]] challenged the American people to develop innovative solutions using Data.gov. San Francisco, the City of New York, the State of California,{{cite web|url=http://ca.gov/data |title=CA.Gov|accessdate=2010-02-14|work=State Of California}} the State of Utah,{{cite web|url=http://www.utah.gov/data |title=Data-Utah.Gov|accessdate=2010-02-14|work=State Of Utah}} the State of Michigan,{{cite web|url=http://www.michigan.gov/data/ |title=State of Michigan-Data|accessdate=2010-02-14|work=State Of Michigan}} and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/data/ |title=Data-Mass.Gov|accessdate=2010-02-14|work=Commonwealth of Massauchussets}} have launched public access websites modeled after Data.gov. Internationally, over 46 countries have launched open data sites patterned after Data.Gov, some using the U.S. Data.gov software which was made open source and made available on GitHub. Additionally, states, cities and counties have launched sites, notably{{cite web|url=http://www.data.gov/open-gov/|title=Open Government|work=Data.gov}}[[Open Government in Canada|some cities in Canada]], and the UK are following suit.{{cite web|url=http://data.gov.uk |title=data.gov.uk|accessdate=2010-02-14|work=HM Government, United Kingdom}} ====IT Dashboard==== [[File:Obama testing the Federal Government IT Dashboard.jpg|thumb|President Barack Obama testing the IT Dashboard]] On June 30, 2009, at the [[Personal Democracy Forum]] in New York,{{cite web |url=http://techpresident.com/blog-entry/pdf-09-kundra-unveils-it-spending-dashboard |title=PdF '09: Kundra Unveils IT Spending Dashboard|accessdate=2010-02-14 |last=Scola |first=Nancy |date=2009-06-30 |work=techPresident, Personal Democracy Forum}} Vivek Kundra, unveiled the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090813013856/http://it.usaspending.gov/ IT Dashboard] that tracks over $76 billion in Federal IT spending.{{Cite web |url=http://it.usaspending.gov/ |title=Federal IT Dashboard |access-date=2009-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813013856/http://it.usaspending.gov/ |archive-date=2009-08-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The IT Dashboard is part of [http://www.USASpending.gov USASpending.gov] to track all government spending.{{cite web|url=http://www.usaspending.gov/|title=Home|publisher=}} The IT Dashboard is designed to provide CIOs of individual government agencies, the public and agency leaders unprecedented visibility into the operations and performance of Federal IT investments (spending), and the ability to provide and receive direct feedback to those directly accountable.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/01/technology/01dashboard.html?_r=2 |title=Online Tool Will Track U.S. Tech Spending |accessdate=2010-02-14 |last=Lohr |first=Steve |date=2009-06-30 |work=New York Times}} In January 2010, Kundra followed up the work on the IT Dashboard with TechStat accountability sessions.{{cite web |url=http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2010/02/09/techstat-meetings-kundra.aspx |title=Federal CIO pursues relentless efficiency via TechStat meetings |accessdate=2010-02-14 |last=Weigelt |first=Matthew |date=2010-02-09 |work=Washington Technology}} These sessions are designed to turn around, halt or terminate at-risk and failing IT projects in the federal government. It allows agency CIOs, CFOs, and other key stakeholders to find solutions for IT projects that are over budget, behind schedule, or under-performing. ====Cloud Computing==== Kundra launched the federal government strategy and the cloud computing portal [[Apps.gov]] at [[NASA Ames Research Center|NASA's Ames Research Center]], [[Moffett Field, California|Moffett Field in California]], on September 15, 2009.NASA Ames Research Center, (2009-09-15) [http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/features/2009/cloud_computing.html "NASA Ames Hosts White House CIO"], Retrieved (2010-01-17) Apps.gov is a new service provided by the GSAGSA [https://www.apps.gov/cloud/advantage/main/start_page.do "Apps.Gov"], Retrieved (2010-01-17) where federal agencies can subscribe to IT services. Kundra saw the cloud as an alternative to hardware investments, as means to reduce IT costs, and to shift focus of federal IT from infrastructure management to strategic projects. This initiative aims to use commercially derived technologies to promote software tools, vast data storage and data sharing, and to foster collaboration across all federal agencies. [[Howard Schmidt]], White House cybersecurity coordinator, will work closely with the Federal CIO and CTO with respect to cloud initiativesFederal News Radio (2010-02-11) [http://www.federalnewsradio.com/index.php?nid=249&sid=1876391 "Cybersecurity coordinator Howard Schmidt discusses cloud"], retrieved (2010-02-15) and has the responsibility of orchestrating all cybersecurity activities across the government.Phillips, Macon (2009-12-22) [http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2009/12/22/introducing-new-cybersecurity-coordinator "Introducing the New Cybersecurity Coordinator"], The White House, retrieved (2010-02-15) On December 9, 2010, Kundra published the "25 Point Implementation Plan to Reform Federal Information Technology Management", which included Cloud First as one of its top priorities for achieving IT efficiency. Cloud First required each agency to identify three cloud initiatives.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/kundra-takes-on-federal-it-reform/2011/04/11/AFMwY5cE_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Marjorie | last=Censer | title=Kundra takes on federal IT reform | date=2011-04-25}} He announced his decision to leave the federal government and join [[Harvard University]] within 7 months of this strategy, too short for any of cloud first initiatives to have demonstrated cost savings.{{cite web|url=http://www.gsaig.gov/?LinkServID=1C91FE07-FF0A-7F2A-F5EC7659D924AE6D&showMeta=0|title=GSA Office of Inspector General|publisher=}} After a short 5 months at Harvard he left to join [[Salesforce.com]], a cloud SaaS and PaaS provider. The first major cloud project during his tenure was GSA's migration of e-mail/Lotus Notes to the Gmail and Salesforce.com's platform. GSA awarded a contract for e-mail in December 2010 and a five-year contract to Salesforce in August 2011. A September 2012 Inspector General report found the savings and cost analysis not verifiable and recommended GSA update its cost analysis. GSA office of CIO was unable to provide documentation supporting its analysis regarding the initial projected savings for government staffing and contractor support. The audit found that the agency could neither verify those savings nor clearly determine if the cloud migration is meeting agency expectations despite initial claims that indicated 50% http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2010/12/02/unisys-google-apps-gsa.aspxs cost savings {{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/16/salesforce-hires-vivek-kundra-and-looks-overseas/ | work=The New York Times | first=Quentin | last=Hardy | title=Salesforce Hires Vivek Kundra and Looks Overseas | date=2012-01-16}} ====Management Reforms==== Kundra published a 25-point implementation plan[http://cio.gov/documents/25-Point-Implementation-Plan-to-Reform-Federal%20IT.pdf 25-Point Implementation Plan to Reform], cio.gov to reform how the federal government manages information technology. The execution plan follows his decision to reevaluate some of the government's most troubled IT projects.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704488404575442021240390314?KEYWORDS=vivek+kundra|work=The Wall Street Journal|first=Amy|last=Schatz|title=U.S. Reviews Tech Spending|date=2010-08-23}} Of 38 projects reviewed, four have been canceled,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/10/AR2010121006099.html|work=The Washington Post|first=Marjorie|last=Censer|title=Agencies have deadline to name services destined for Web|date=2010-12-13}} 11 have been rescoped, and 12 have cut the time for delivery of functionality down by more than half, from two to three years down to an average of 8 months, achieving a total of $3 billion in lifecycle budget reductions, according to [http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/12/10/saving-money-government-it whitehouse.gov] [[File:Saving Money on Government IT.jpg|basic|This image illustrates the work done by US Chief Information Officer Vivek Kundra to reform Federal IT management]] ====Suspension==== On March 13, 2009, Kundra was placed on indefinite leave following an [[FBI]] raid on his former D.C. office and the arrest of two individuals in relation to a bribery investigation.Eric Kangel, "Obama put new CIO Vivek kundra on suspension," ''Business Insider'' March 13, 2009 [http://www.businessinsider.com/obama-puts-new-cio-vivek-kundra-on-suspension-2009-3 link]{{cite news|title=Kundra Reinstated as Federal CIO |url=http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2009/03/17/kundra-reinstated.aspx|date=March 18, 2009|publisher=[[Washington Technology]]|accessdate=2009-10-29}} Kundra returned to duties after five days with no finding of wrongdoing on his part. ===Post-Obama administration career=== Kundra left his post as chief information officer in August 2011 to accept an academic fellowship at Harvard University, conducting research at both the [[Berkman Center for Internet & Society]] and the [[Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy]].Office of Management and Budget (2011-06-16) [http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/06/16/our-nation-s-first-federal-cio "Our Nation’s First Federal CIO"], The White House, retrieved (2011-06-18)Harvard University (2011). [http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/newsroom/vivek_kundra_fellowship U.S. C.I.O. to Serve Joint Fellowship at Harvard], retrieved August 3, 2011. In January 2012 Kundra joined [[Salesforce.com]] as Executive Vice President of Emerging Markets.{{cite web|url=http://www.salesforce.com/company/news-press/press-releases/2012/01/120116.jsp|title=Vivek Kundra Joins Salesforce.com as Executive Vice President of Emerging Markets|publisher=}} On May 16, 2018{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/05/17/sprinklr-hires-former-fed-cio-vivek-kundra-as-coo/|title=Vivek Kundra Joins Sprinklr as COO|publisher=}} Kundra left [[Salesforce]] and joined the private start-up [[Sprinklr]] as [[Chief Operating Officer]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sprinklr.com/about-us/#leadership|title=Sprinklr Leadership Team|publisher=}} == Professional recognition == In May 2011, Kundra was selected by [[EMC Corporation]] for their Data Hero Visionary Award for his pioneering work under the Obama Administration to reform how the Federal government manages and uses information technology.PR Newswire, [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/united-states-cio-vivek-kundra-receives-2011-data-hero-visionary-award-121528944.html "United States CIO Vivek Kundra Receives 2011 Data Hero Visionary Award"] EMC states that, "Kundra has led the nation to seek innovative solutions to lower the cost of government operations, while exploring ways to fundamentally change the way the public sector and the public interact". In March 2011, Kundra was selected by the World Economic Forum as a Young Global Leader for his professional accomplishments, commitment to society and potential to contribute to shaping the future of the world.Zopf, Yann (2011-03-11),[http://www.weforum.org/news/world-economic-forum-announces-young-global-leaders-2011-north-america "World Economic Forum Announces Young Global Leaders 2011 (North America)"], World Economic Forum Kundra was awarded the 2010 National Cyber Security Leadership AwardSANS Institute, (2010-11-16), [https://www.sans.org/cyber-security-leadership/2010/ "2010 National Cyber Security Leadership Award Winners"] by the SANS Institute for uncovering more than $300 million each year in wasted federal spending on ineffective certification and accreditation reporting and demonstrating an alternative approach called "continuous monitoring" that provides more effective security for federal systems at lower costs. Kundra was named Chief of the Year on December 21, 2009, by [[InformationWeek]] for driving unprecedented change in federal IT.{{cite news|title=Chief Of The Year: Vivek Kundra |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/government/leadership/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=222002611|date=December 21, 2009|publisher=[[Information Week]]|accessdate=2010-01-02}} Kundra was named by [[InfoWorld]] among the top 25 CTO's in the country.{{cite journal |author = Gruman, Galen |date = 2008-06-02 |title = The best CTOs of 2008 |url = http://www.infoworld.com/article/08/06/02/23FE-cto25-kundra_1.html |publisher = InfoWorld |accessdate = 2009-03-05 }} He was also selected as a 2008 [[MIT Sloan School of Management|MIT Sloan]] CIO Symposium Award Finalist on 'Balancing Innovation and Cost Leadership'. Both organizations cited the "stock market" approach to IT portfolio management that Kundra implemented for the District of Columbia. The system measured project performance and allocated IT investments similar to the way the public companies trade on the stock market. [[John F. Kennedy School of Government|Harvard Kennedy School of Government's]] Ash Institute also awarded the Innovations in American Government Award (2009) to "District of Columbia's Data Feeds: Democratization of Government Data".The Ash Institute for Democratic Governance and Innovation (2009-09-15) [http://ashinstitute.harvard.edu/corporate_site/innovations/innovations_news/district_of_columbia_s_data_feeds_wins_innovations_in_american_government_award “District of Columbia's Data Feeds Wins Innovations in American Government Award”] John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University. The project spearheaded by Kundra, Mayor Fenty, and CPO David Gragan{{cite journal|author=Van der Veen, Chad |date=2009-09-14 |title=D.C.'s Data Feeds Wins Kennedy School's Innovations in American Government Award |url=http://www.govtech.com/gt/articles/723258 |publisher=Government Technology |accessdate=2009-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531040932/http://www.govtech.com/gt/articles/723258 |archivedate=May 31, 2010 }} was cited for "increase in civic participation, government accountability, and transparency in D.C. government practices" through sites like the Digital Public SquareDistrict of Columbia [http://dps.dc.gov/ “DC Digital Public Square”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111230516/http://dps.dc.gov/ |date=2009-11-11 }} and the DC Data Catalog.District of Columbia [http://data.octo.dc.gov/ “DC Data Catalog”] Kundra was recognized as the 2008 Government Sector IT Executive of the Year by the [[Tech Council of Maryland]]. The organization cited Kundra's efforts to increase public access to government information and services through live data feeds and data sets.{{cite journal|author=Michelle Ferrone |date=2008-11-07 |title=The Tech Council of Maryland Announces Award Winners of 2008 CIO&CTO LIVE! Awards |url=http://www.techcouncilmd.com/News/tcmnews_110708.html |publisher=Tech Council MD |accessdate=2009-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106003044/http://www.techcouncilmd.com/News/tcmnews_110708.html |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }} Kundra was also a recipient of the Federal 100 Award{{cite journal |author = Monroe, John S. |date = 2009-02-13 |title = 2009 Federal 100 Winners |url = http://1105govinfoevents.com/fed100/2009_Fed_100_winners_list.pdf |format=PDF|publisher = Federal Computer Week |accessdate = 2009-11-09 }} for significant contributions to the federal information technology community.{{cite journal |author = Monroe, John S. |date = 2009-02-13 |title = FCW announces the 2009 Federal 100 award winners |url = http://www.fcw.com/Articles/2009/02/13/FCW-announces-Fed-100-winners.aspx |publisher = Federal Computer Week |accessdate = 2009-11-09 }} ==See also== * [[Government 2.0]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.cio.gov Federal CIO Council] *{{C-SPAN|vivekkundra}} *[http://www.ctovision.com/2008/11/vivek-kundra-democratizing-data-and-putting-it-in-the-public-domain.html 'Democratizing Data and Putting it in the Public Domain'], November 20, 2008 *[http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2009/03/federal_cio_viv.html Live On Video: Federal CIO Vivek Kundra In His Own Words], ''InformationWeek'' Wolfe's Den blog - March 6, 2009 *[http://www.govtech.com/gt/624870 Kundra on Democratizing Data] [[Government Technology Magazine]], March 2009 * [http://dqindia.ciol.com/content/top_stories/2012/112020301.asp The Most Influential Global Indians in Technology] [[Dataquest]] {{Obama Executive Office|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kundra, Vivek}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:American people of Indian descent]] [[Category:Chief information officers]] [[Category:Tanzanian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Obama administration personnel]] [[Category:Technology evangelists]] [[Category:Indian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:University of Maryland, College Park alumni]] [[Category:Washington, D.C. [[File:Wilkinson-coupler.svg|thumb|Power divider in microstrip technology]] In the field of [[microwave]] engineering and circuit design, the '''Wilkinson Power Divider''' is a specific class of [[power divider]] circuit that can achieve isolation between the output ports while maintaining a matched condition on all ports. The Wilkinson design can also be used as a power combiner because it is made up of [[passive components]] and hence reciprocal. First published by Ernest J. Wilkinson in 1960,E.J. Wilkinson, "An N-way Power Divider", ''IRE Trans. on Microwave Theory and Techniques'', vol. 8, p. 116-118, Jan. 1960, doi: 10.1109/TMTT.1960.1124668 this circuit finds wide use in [[radio frequency]] communication systems utilizing multiple channels since the high degree of isolation between the output ports prevents [[crosstalk]] between the individual channels. It uses [[Quarter-wave impedance transformer|quarter wave transformers]], which can be easily fabricated as quarter wave lines on [[printed circuit board]]s. It is also possible to use other forms of transmission line (e.g. coaxial cable) or lumped circuit elements (inductors and capacitors).{{cite web|title=Overview and essentials of the Wilkinson divider splitter combiner |url=http://www.radio-electronics.com/info/rf-technology-design/coupler-combiner-splitter/wilkinson-splitter-combiner-divider.php|publisher=Radio-electronics.com|accessdate=6 February 2013}} == Theory == [[File:Simulation result of a Wilkinson Power Divider (WPD).jpg|thumb|400px|right|Picture shows a typical output expected from a Wilkinson power divider. The S_{21}, S_{31} are almost -3 dB, and the S_{11} is low near the design frequency.]] [[File:WPD2.jpg|thumb|400px|right|Picture demonstrates a very high isolation between output ports (port 2 & 3) of a Wilkinson power divider]] The [[scattering parameters]] for the common case of a 2-way equal-split Wilkinson power divider at the design frequency is given byD.M. Pozar, ''Microwave Engineering'', Third Edition, John Wiley & Sons: New York, 2005 : [S]=\frac{-j}{\sqrt{2}}\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} Inspection of the ''S'' matrix reveals that the network is reciprocal (S_{ij}=S_{ji}), that the terminals are matched (S_{11}, S_{22}, S_{33}=0), that the output terminals are isolated (S_{23}, S_{32}=0), and that equal power division is achieved (S_{21}=S_{31}). The non-[[unitary matrix]] results from the fact that the network is lossy. An ideal Wilkinson divider would yield S_{21}=S_{31} = -3\,\text{dB} =10 \log_{10} (\frac{1}{2}). Network theorem governs that a divider cannot satisfy all three conditions (being matched, reciprocal and loss-less) at the same time. Wilkinson divider satisfies the first two (matched and reciprocal), and cannot satisfy the last one (being loss-less). Hence, there is some loss occurring in the network. No loss occurs when the signals at ports 2 and 3 are in phase and have equal magnitude. In case of noise input to ports 2 and 3, the noise level at port 1 does not increase, half of the noise power is dissipated in the resistor. By cascading, the input power might be divided to any n-number of outputs. '''Unequal/Asymmetric Division Through Wilkinson Divider''' If the arms for port 2 and 3 are connected with un-equal impedances, then asymmetric division of power can be achieved. When characteristic impedance is Z_{0}, and one wants to split power as P_{2} and P_{3}, and P_{2} ≠ P_{3}, then the design can be created following the equations: A new constant K is defined for ease of expression, where K^{2}= \frac{P_{3}}{P_{2}} [[File:Unequal Wilkinson.png|thumb|400px|center|Impedances are different in two branches to achieve unequal splitting of power. The output impedances of the two branches are also different.]] Then the design guideline is:
Z_{02} =Z_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1+K^2}{K^3}}
Z_{03} =Z_{0} \sqrt{K(1+K^2)} = K^2 Z_{03}

R =Z_{0} (K+\frac{1}{K})
It is to be noted that it can be set K=1 the above expression, and one would obtain the equal-splitting Wilkinson Divider. == See also == *[[Power dividers and directional couplers]] == References == {{reflist|1}} ==External links== *[http://www.changpuak.ch/electronics/wilkinson_power_split_2.php Online Wilkinson Power Split Calculator] *[http://www.changpuak.ch/electronics/resistive_power_split.php Online Resistive Power Split Calculator] *[http://www.changpuak.ch/electronics/coaxial_power_split.php Online Coaxial Power Split Calculator] *[http://www.radio-electronics.com/info/rf-technology-design/coupler-combiner-splitter/wilkinson-splitter-combiner-divider.php Wilkinson power divider tutorial] with other power divider / combiner pages {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilkinson Power Divider}} [[Category:Microwave technology]] [[Category:Radio electronics]]

{{distinguish|text= the ATI [[Xenos (graphics chip)|Xenos]], or [[Xenon (processor)|Xenon]]}} {{Lead too short|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox CPU |name=Xeon Phi |image=|image_size=150px |slowest=1.053 |fastest=1.7 |numcores={{unbulleted list|57-61 (X100 Series)|64-72 (x200 Series)}} |l1cache=32 [[Kibibyte|KB]] per core |l2cache=512 [[Kibibyte|KB]] per core |created=2012 |transistors=[[22 nanometer|22 nm transistors]] ([[Tri-Gate]])
[[14 nanometer|14 nm transistors]] ([[FinFET|Tri-Gate]]) |arch1=[[x86-64]] |extensions2=[[Advanced Vector Extensions|AVX]], [[Advanced Vector Extensions 2|AVX2]], [[Advanced Vector Extensions 512]] |sock1=[[PCI Express|PCIe 3.0]] x16 |sock2=LGA3647 |brand1={{unbulleted list|[[Xeon Phi 3100]]|[[Xeon Phi 5100]]|[[Xeon Phi 7100]]|[[Xeon Phi 7200]]}} }} '''Xeon Phi''' is a series of [[x86]] [[Manycore processor|manycore processors]] designed and made entirely by [[Intel]]. They are intended for use in supercomputers, servers, and high-end workstations. Its architecture allows use of standard programming languages and APIs such as [[OpenMP]].https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/best-known-methods-for-using-openmp-on-intel-many-integrated-core-intel-mic-architecture Since it was originally based on an earlier GPU design by Intel, it shares application areas with GPUs.{{cn|date=October 2017}} The main difference between Xeon Phi and a [[GPGPU]] like [[Nvidia Tesla]] is that Xeon Phi, with an x86-compatible core, can, with less modification, run software that was originally targeted at a standard x86 CPU.{{cn|date=October 2017}} Initially in the form of [[PCIe]]-based add-on cards, a second generation product, codenamed ''Knights Landing'' was announced in June 2013. These second generation chips could be used as a standalone CPU, rather than just as an add-in card. [[File:Tianhe-2.jpg|thumb|The [[Tianhe-2]] supercomputer uses Xeon Phi processors.]] In June 2013, the [[Tianhe-2]] supercomputer at the [[National Supercomputer Center in Guangzhou]] (NSCC-GZ) was announced{{cite web|title=TOP500 - June 2013|url=https://www.top500.org/lists/2013/06/|work=TOP500 - June 2013|publisher=TOP500|accessdate=June 18, 2013}} as the world's fastest supercomputer ({{As of|2018|06|lc=y}}, it is {{Numero|4}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.top500.org/lists/2018/06/|title=June 2018 {{!}} TOP500 Supercomputer Sites|website=www.top500.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}). It uses Intel Xeon Phi coprocessors and [[Ivy Bridge (microarchitecture)|Ivy Bridge]]-EP Xeon processors to achieve 33.86 petaFLOPS.{{cite web|url=https://newsroom.intel.com/community/intel_newsroom/blog/2013/06/17/intel-powers-the-worlds-fastest-supercomputer-reveals-new-and-future-high-performance-computing-technologies|title=Intel Powers the World's Fastest Supercomputer, Reveals New and Future High Performance Computing Technologies|accessdate=June 21, 2013}} ==History== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Code Name !! Technology !! Comments |- | Knights Ferry || 45 nm || offered as PCIe card; derived from Larrabee project |- | Knights Corner || 22 nm || derived from P54C; vector processing unit; first device to be announced as ''Xeon Phi'' |- | Knights Landing || 14 nm || Abbr.: KNL;https://github.com/gz/rust-x86/blob/master/x86data/perfmon_data/mapfile.csv derived from Silvermont/Airmont (Intel Atom);[https://www.golem.de/news/knights-landing-intel-veroeffentlicht-xeon-phi-mit-bis-zu-7-teraflops-1606-121642.html] AVX-512 |- | Knights Hill || 10 nm || canceled |- | Knights Mill || 14 nm || nearly identical to Knights Landing but optimized for deep learning |} ===Background=== The [[Larrabee (microarchitecture)|Larrabee microarchitecture]] (in development since 2006{{citation |url=https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1029138/new-from-intel-its-mini-cores |title= New from Intel: It's Mini-Cores! |author= Charlie Demerjian |date= July 3, 2006 |work= www.theinquirer.net |publisher= [[The Inquirer]]}}) introduced very wide (512-bit) [[SIMD]] units to a [[x86]] architecture based processor design, extended to a [[Cache coherence|cache-coherent]] multiprocessor system connected via a ring bus to memory; each core was capable of four-way multithreading. Due to the design being intended for GPU as well as general purpose computing, the Larrabee chips also included specialised hardware for texture sampling.{{cite journal|last2=Cavin|first2=D.|last3=Espasa|first3=E.|last4=Grochowski|first4=T.|last5=Juan|first5=M.|last6=Hanrahan|first6=P.|last7=Carmean|first7=S.|last8=Sprangle|first8=A.|last9=Forsyth|first9=J.|date=August 2008|title=Larrabee: A Many-Core x86 Architecture for Visual Computing|url=https://download-software.intel.com/sites/default/files/m/9/4/9/larrabee_manycore.pdf|format=PDF|journal=[[ACM Transactions on Graphics]]|series=Proceedings of ACM SIGGRAPH 2008|volume=27|issue=3|pages=18:11–18:11|doi=10.1145/1360612.1360617|issn=0730-0301|first1=L.|last1=Seiler|first10=R.|last10=Abrash|first11=R.|last11=Dubey|first12=E.|last12=Junkins|first13=T.|last13=Lake|first14=P.|last14=Sugerman|accessdate=2008-08-06}}{{citation |url=https://www.stanford.edu/class/ee380/Abstracts/100106-slides.pdf |title= SIMD Programming with Larrabee |author= Tom Forsyth |publisher= [[Intel]] |work= www.stanford.edu }} The project to produce a retail GPU product directly from the Larrabee research project was terminated in May 2010.{{citation |url= https://www.anandtech.com/show/3738/intel-kills-larrabee-gpu-will-not-bring-a-discrete-graphics-product-to-market |title= Intel Kills Larrabee GPU, Will Not Bring a Discrete Graphics Product to Market\ |author= Ryan Smith |date= May 25, 2010 |publisher= [[AnandTech]] |website= www.anandtech.com }} Another contemporary Intel research project implementing x86 architecture on a many-multicore processor was the '[[Single-chip Cloud Computer]]' (prototype introduced 2009{{citation|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/183653/intel_48core_singlechip_cloud_computer_improves_power_efficiency.html |title= Intel 48-Core "Single-Chip Cloud Computer" Improves Power Efficiency |author= Tony Bradley |publisher= [[PC World (magazine)|PCWorld]] |work= www.pcworld.com |date= December 3, 2009}}), a design mimicking a [[cloud computing]] computer datacentre on a single chip with multiple independent cores: the prototype design included 48 cores per chip with hardware support for selective frequency and voltage control of cores to maximize energy efficiency, and incorporated a [[Mesh networking|mesh network]] for inter-chip messaging. The design lacked cache-coherent cores and focused on principles that would allow the design to scale to many more cores.{{citation|url= http://techresearch.intel.com/ProjectDetails.aspx?Id=1 |title= Intel Research : Single-Chip Cloud Computer |publisher= [[Intel]] |work= techresearch.intel.com}} The [[Teraflops Research Chip]] (prototype unveiled 2007{{citation|url= https://www.pcworld.com/article/128924/intel_tests_chip_design_with_80core_processor.html |title=Intel Tests Chip Design With 80-Core Processor|author= Ben Ames|publisher= IDG News |date= February 11, 2007 |work= www.pcworld.com}}) is an experimental 80-core chip with two floating point units per core, implementing a 96-bit [[Very long instruction word|VLIW]] architecture instead of the x86 architecture.{{cite web|url=http://www.xbitlabs.com/news/cpu/display/20070212224710.html|title=Intel Details 80-Core Teraflops Research Chip - X-bit labs|work=xbitlabs.com|accessdate=August 27, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205070552/http://www.xbitlabs.com/news/cpu/display/20070212224710.html|archivedate=5 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} The project investigated intercore communication methods, per-chip power management, and achieved 1.01 [[TFLOPS]] at 3.16 GHz consuming 62 W of power.{{citation|url=https://download.intel.com/pressroom/kits/Teraflops/Teraflops_Research_Chip_Overview.pdf |title= Intel’s Teraflops Research Chip |publisher= [[Intel]] |work= download.intel.com}}{{citation |url= http://www.xbitlabs.com/news/cpu/display/20070212224710.html |title= Intel Details 80-Core Teraflops Research Chip |author= Anton Shilov |date= February 12, 2007 |publisher= Xbit laboratories |work= www.xbitlabs.com |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150205070552/http://www.xbitlabs.com/news/cpu/display/20070212224710.html |archivedate= 5 February 2015 |df= dmy-all }} ==={{anchor|Knights Ferry}}Knights Ferry=== Intel's Many Integrated Core (MIC) prototype board, named ''Knights Ferry'', incorporating a processor codenamed ''Aubrey Isle'' was announced May 31, 2010. The product was stated to be a derivative of the ''Larrabee'' project and other Intel research including the ''Single-chip Cloud Computer''.{{citation |url= http://www.zdnet.co.uk/news/desktop-hardware/2010/06/01/intel-unveils-many-core-knights-platform-for-hpc-40089093/ |title= Intel unveils many-core Knights platform for HPC |author= Rupert Goodwins |publisher= [[ZDNet]] |date= June 1, 2010 |work= www.zdnet.co.uk}}{{citation |url= https://www.intel.com/pressroom/archive/releases/2010/20100531comp.htm |title= Intel News Release : Intel Unveils New Product Plans dor High-Performance Computing |date= May 31, 2010 |work= www.intel.com |publisher= [[Intel]]}} The development product was offered as a PCIe card with 32 in-order cores at up to 1.2 GHz with four threads per core, 2 GB GDDR5 memory,{{citation|title=Runners and riders in GPU steeplechase|date=June 24, 2010|url=http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/gilesm/talks/nag_tpc10.pdf|author=Mike Giles|work=people.maths.ox.ac.uk|pages=8–10}} and 8 MB coherent L2 cache (256 KB per core with 32 KB L1 cache), and a power requirement of ~300 W, built at a 45 nm process. In the ''Aubrey Isle'' core a 1,024-bit ring bus (512-bit bi-directional) connects processors to main memory.{{citation |url= http://www.many-core.group.cam.ac.uk/ukgpucc2/talks/Elgar.pdf |title= Intel Many Integrated Core Architecture |date= December 2010 |publisher= Intel |work= www.many-core.group.cam.ac.uk |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120402211714/http://www.many-core.group.cam.ac.uk/ukgpucc2/talks/Elgar.pdf |archivedate= 2 April 2012 |df= dmy-all }} Single board performance has exceeded 750 GFLOPS. The prototype boards only support single precision floating point instructions.{{citation |url= https://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4217092/OEMs-show-systems-with-Intel-MIC-chips |title= OEMs show systems with Intel MIC chips |author= Rick Merritt |date=June 20, 2011 |work= www.eetimes.com |publisher=[[EE Times]]}} Initial developers included [[CERN]], [[Korea Institute of Science and Technology Information]] (KISTI) and [[Leibniz Supercomputing Centre]]. Hardware vendors for prototype boards included IBM, SGI, HP, Dell and others.{{citation |url= http://www.linleygroup.com/newsletters/newsletter_detail.php?num=4729 |title= Intel Shows MIC Progress |date= July 18, 2011 |author= Tom R. Halfhill |work= www.linleygroup.com|publisher= [[The Linley Group]]}} ==={{anchor|Knights Corner}}Knights Corner=== The ''Knights Corner'' product line is made at a 22 nm process size, using Intel's [[Trigate Transistors|Tri-gate]] technology with more than 50 cores per chip, and is Intel's first many-cores commercial product.{{citation |url= http://www.thinq.co.uk/2011/6/20/intel-pushes-hpc-space-knights-corner/ |title= Intel pushes for HPC space with Knights Corner |publisher= [[Net Communities Limited, UK]] |work= www.thinq.co.uk |date= June 20, 2011 |author= Gareth Halfacree}} In June 2011, [[Silicon Graphics International|SGI]] announced a partnership with Intel to use the MIC architecture in its high performance computing products.{{citation |url= http://news.techeye.net/hardware/sgi-wants-intel-for-super-supercomputer |title= SGI wants Intel for super supercomputer |date= June 20, 2011 |author= Andrea Petrou |work= news.techeye.net |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110916013050/http://news.techeye.net/hardware/sgi-wants-intel-for-super-supercomputer |archivedate= 16 September 2011 |df= dmy-all }} In September 2011, it was announced that the [[Texas Advanced Computing Center]] (TACC) will use Knights Corner cards in their 10 petaFLOPS "Stampede" supercomputer, providing 8 petaFLOPS of compute power.{{citation |url= http://www.tacc.utexas.edu/news/press-releases/2011/stampede |title= "Stampede's" Comprehensive Capabilities to Bolster U.S. Open Science Computational Resources |date= September 22, 2011 |work= www.tacc.utexas.edu|publisher= [[Texas Advanced Computing Center]]}} According to "Stampede: A Comprehensive Petascale Computing Environment" the "second generation Intel (Knights Landing) MICs will be added when they become available, increasing Stampede's aggregate peak performance to at least 15 PetaFLOPS."{{cite web|url=http://www.ieeecluster.org/2011/images/program/Stampede_Abstracts.pdf|title=Stampede: A Comprehensive Petascale Computing Environment|work=IEEE Cluster 2011 Special Topic|accessdate=November 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AyMCTibp?url=http://www.ieeecluster.org/2011/images/program/Stampede_Abstracts.pdf|archivedate=26 September 2012|df=dmy-all}} On November 15, 2011, Intel showed an early silicon version of a Knights Corner processor.{{citation|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/intel-knights-corner-mic-co-processor,14002.html |title=Intel's Knights ScaleMP vSMP Foundation to Support Intel Xeon Phi |work= www.ScaleMP.com |publisher= [[ScaleMP]] |date= June 20, 2012}} An important component of the Intel Xeon Phi coprocessor’s core is its vector processing unit (VPU).https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-xeon-phi-coprocessor-codename-knights-corner The VPU features a novel 512-bit SIMD instruction set, officially known as Intel Initial Many Core Instructions (Intel IMCI). Thus, the VPU can execute 16 [[Single-precision floating-point format|single-precision]] (SP) or 8 [[Double-precision floating-point format|double-precision]] (DP) operations per cycle. The VPU also supports Fused Multiply-Add (FMA) instructions and hence can execute 32 SP or 16 DP floating point operations per cycle. It also provides support for integers. The VPU also features an Extended Math Unit (EMU) that can execute operations such as reciprocal, square root, and logarithm, thereby allowing these operations to be executed in a vector fashion with high bandwidth. The EMU operates by calculating polynomial approximations of these functions. On November 12, 2012, Intel announced two Xeon Phi coprocessor families using the 22 nm process size: the Xeon Phi 3100 and the Xeon Phi 5110P.{{cite news|url=https://newsroom.intel.com/community/intel_newsroom/blog/2012/11/12/intel-delivers-new-architecture-for-discovery-with-intel-xeon-phi-coprocessors|title=Intel Delivers New Architecture for Discovery with Intel Xeon Phi Coprocessors|date=November 12, 2012|publisher=Intel|author=IntelPR|accessdate=December 12, 2012}}{{cite news |title=Intel ships 60-core Xeon Phi processor |author=Agam Shah |publisher=Computerworld |url=https://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9233498/Intel_ships_60_core_Xeon_Phi_processor |date=November 12, 2012 |accessdate=December 12, 2012}}{{cite news |title=The Xeon Phi at work at TACC |author=Johan De Gelas |publisher=AnandTech |url=https://www.anandtech.com/show/6451/the-xeon-phi-at-work-at-tacc |date=November 14, 2012 |accessdate=December 12, 2012}} The Xeon Phi 3100 will be capable of more than 1 teraFLOPS of double precision floating point instructions with 240 GB/sec memory bandwidth at 300 W. The Xeon Phi 5110P will be capable of 1.01 teraFLOPS of double precision floating point instructions with 320 GB/sec memory bandwidth at 225 W. The Xeon Phi 7120P will be capable of 1.2 teraFLOPS of double precision floating point instructions with 352 GB/sec memory bandwidth at 300 W. On June 17, 2013, the [[Tianhe-2]] supercomputer was announced by [[TOP500]] as the world's fastest. Tianhe-2 used Intel Ivy Bridge Xeon and Xeon Phi processors to achieve 33.86 petaFLOPS. It was the fastest on the list for two and a half years, lastly in November 2015.{{cite web |title=Tianhe-2 (MilkyWay-2) |publisher=Top500.org |url=https://top500.org/system/177999 |date=November 14, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2016}} ====Design and programming==== The cores of Knights Corner are based on a modified version of [[P5 (microarchitecture)#P54C|P54C]] design, used in the original Pentium.{{cite web |url=https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/133541-intels-64-core-champion-in-depth-on-xeon-phi |title=Intel’s 50-core champion: In-depth on Xeon Phi |last1=Hruska |first1=Joel |last2= |first2= |date=July 30, 2012 |work=ExtremeTech |publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc. |accessdate=December 2, 2012}} The basis of the Intel MIC architecture is to leverage x86 legacy by creating an x86-compatible multiprocessor architecture that can use existing parallelization software tools. Programming tools include [[OpenMP]],{{cite conference |url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-40698-0_4 |last=Barker |first=J |last2=Bowden |first2=J |year=2013 |title=Manycore Parallelism through OpenMP |conference=IWOMP |book-title=OpenMP in the Era of Low Power Devices and Accelerators |publisher=Springer |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 8122}} [[OpenCL]],{{citation |url= https://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4217092/OEMs-show-systems-with-Intel-MIC-chips |title= OEMs show systems with Intel MIC chips |author= Rick Merritt |date= June 20, 2011 |publisher= [[EE Times]] |work= www.eetimes.com}} [[Cilk]]/[[Cilk Plus]] and specialised versions of Intel's Fortran, C++{{citation |arxiv= 1211.5530|title= Efficient Hybrid Execution of C++ Applications using Intel Xeon Phi Coprocessor |date= November 23, 2012|bibcode= 2012arXiv1211.5530D}} and math libraries.{{citation|url=https://newsroom.intel.com/servlet/JiveServlet/download/2152-4-5220/ISC_Intel_MIC_factsheet.pdf |title=News Fact Sheet: Intel Many Integrated Core (Intel MIC) Architecture ISC'11 Demos and Performance Description |work=newsroom.intel.com |publisher=[[Intel]] |date=June 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324101552/https://newsroom.intel.com/servlet/JiveServlet/download/2152-4-5220/ISC_Intel_MIC_factsheet.pdf |archivedate=March 24, 2012 }} Design elements inherited from the Larrabee project include x86 ISA, 4-way [[Simultaneous multithreading|SMT]] per core, 512-bit SIMD units, 32 KB L1 instruction cache, 32 KB L1 data cache, coherent L2 cache (512 KB per core[https://cug.org/proceedings/cug2013_proceedings/includes/files/pap199.pdf Tesla vs. Xeon Phi vs. Radeon. A Compiler Writer’s Perspective] // The Portland Group (PGI), CUG 2013 Proceedings), and ultra-wide ring bus connecting processors and memory. 2013 |- |} ==={{anchor|Knights Landing}}Knights Landing=== Code name for the second generation MIC architecture product from Intel. Intel officially first revealed details of its second generation Intel Xeon Phi products on June 17, 2013. Intel said that the next generation of Intel MIC Architecture-based products will be available in two forms, as a coprocessor or a host processor (CPU), and be manufactured using Intel's [[14 nanometer|14 nm]] process technology. Knights Landing products will include integrated on-package memory for significantly higher memory bandwidth. Knights Landing contains up to 72 [[Airmont (microarchitecture)|Airmont]] (Atom) cores with four threads per core,{{cite web|url=https://wccftech.com/intel-xeon-phi-knights-landing-features-integrated-memory-500-gbs-bandwidth-ddr4-memory-support-architecture-detailed/|title=Intel Xeon Phi 'Knights Landing' Features Integrated Memory With 500 GB/s Bandwidth and DDR4 Memory Support - Architecture Detailed|work=WCCFtech|accessdate=August 27, 2015}}{{citation |url=https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/171678-intel-unveils-72-core-x86-knights-landing-cpu-for-exascale-supercomputing |title=Intel unveils 72-core x86 Knights Landing CPU for exascale supercomputing |date=November 26, 2013 |author=Sebastian Anthony |publisher= [[ExtremeTech]]}} using [[LGA 3647]] socket[https://www.tomshardware.com/news/intel-xeon-phi-knights-landing,32121.html Tom's Hardware: Intel Xeon Phi Knights Landing Now Shipping; Omni Path Update, Too]. June 20, 2016 supporting up to 384 GB of "far" DDR4 2133 RAM and 8–16 GB of stacked "near" 3D [[MCDRAM]], a version of the [[Hybrid Memory Cube]]. Each core has two 512-bit vector units and supports [[AVX-512]] SIMD instructions, specifically the Intel AVX-512 Foundational Instructions (AVX-512F) with Intel AVX-512 Conflict Detection Instructions (AVX-512CD), Intel AVX-512 Exponential and Reciprocal Instructions (AVX-512ER), and Intel AVX-512 Prefetch Instructions (AVX-512PF).{{citation |url=https://software.intel.com/en-us/blogs/2013/avx-512-instructions |title=AVX-512 Instructions |date=July 23, 2013 |author=James Reinders |publisher= [[Intel]]}} The [[National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center]] announced that Phase 2 of its newest supercomputing system "Cori" would use Knights Landing Xeon Phi coprocessors.https://www.nersc.gov/users/computational-systems/cori On June 20, 2016, Intel launched the Intel Xeon Phi product family x200 based on the Knights Landing architecture, stressing its applicability to not just traditional simulation workloads, but also to [[machine learning]].[https://vimeo.com/intelpr/review/171590720/0bb679ec36 2016 ISC High Performance: Intel's Rajeeb Hazra Delivers Keynote Address][https://software.intel.com/en-us/blogs/2016/06/20/how-xeon-phi-processors-benefit-machine-learning-deep-learning-apps-and-frameworks How Intel Xeon Phi Processors Benefit Machine Learning/Deep Learning Apps and Frameworks] The model lineup announced at launch included only Xeon Phi of bootable form-factor, but two versions of it: standard processors and processors with integrated Intel [[Omni-Path]] architecture fabric.[https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/processors/xeon/xeon-phi-detail.html Introducing the Intel Xeon Phi Processor – Your Path to Deeper Insight] The latter is denoted by the suffix F in the model number. Integrated fabric is expected to provide better latency at a lower cost than discrete high-performance network cards. On November 14, 2016, the 48th list of [[TOP500]] contained 10 systems using Knights Landing platforms.{{cn|date=August 2017}} The [[PCIe]] based co-processor variant of Knight's Landing was never offered to the general market and was discontinued by August 2017.{{cite news|last1=Larabel|first1=Michael|title=Intel Quietly Drops Xeon Phi 7200 Coprocessors|url=https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=No-More-Xeon-Phi-7200-Cards|accessdate=25 August 2017|publisher=Phoronix|date=24 August 2017}} This included the 7220A, 7240P and 7220P coprocessor cards. Intel announced the product discontinuance during Summer 2018{{cite web |url=https://qdms.intel.com/dm/i.aspx/9C54A9A7-BF37-4496-B268-BD2746EA54D3/PCN116378-00.pdf |title=Product Change Notification 116378 - 00 |accessdate=25 July 2018 |website= Intel.com}} ;Models All models can boost to their peak speeds, adding 200 MHz to their base frequency when running just one or two cores. When running from three to the maximum number of cores, the chips can only boost 100 MHz above the base frequency. |date=November 25, 2014 |author= Eric Gardner |publisher= [[Intel Corporation]]}} Knights Hill was expected to be used in the [[United States Department of Energy]] Aurora supercomputer, to be deployed at [[Argonne National Laboratory]].{{citation|url=https://www.alcf.anl.gov/articles/introducing-aurora|title=Introducing Aurora|date=April 9, 2015|author=ALCF staff}}{{citation|url=https://aurora.alcf.anl.gov/|title=Aurora|date=April 9, 2015|author=ALCF staff}} However, Aurora was delayed in favor of using an "advanced architecture" with a focus on machine learning.{{cite news|last1=Hemsoth|first1=Nicole|title=Some Surprises in the 2018 DoE Budget for Supercomputing|url=https://www.nextplatform.com/2017/05/23/surprises-2018-doe-budget-supercomputing/|accessdate=13 November 2017|publisher=Next Platform|date=23 May 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Brueckner|first1=Rich|title=Is Aurora Morphing into an Exascale AI Supercomputer?|url=https://insidehpc.com/2017/06/told-aurora-morphing-novel-architecture-ai-supercomputer/|accessdate=13 November 2017|publisher=Inside HPC|date=16 June 2017}} In 2017, Intel announced that Knights Hill had been canceled in favor of another architecture built from the ground up to enable [[exascale computing|Exascale computing]] in the future. This new architecture in now expected for 2020–2021.{{cite news|last1=Damkroger|first1=Trish|title=Unleashing high performance computing today and tomorrow|url=https://itpeernetwork.intel.com/unleashing-high-performance-computing/|publisher=Intel IT Peer Network|date=13 November 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Kampman|first1=Jeff|title=Intel quietly kills off next-gen Knights Hill Xeon Phi chips|url=https://techreport.com/news/32829/intel-quietly-kills-off-next-gen-knights-hill-xeon-phi-chips|accessdate=13 November 2017|publisher=Tech Report|date=13 November 2017}} The terms ''Exascale computing'' and ''high performance computing'' (HPC) got meanwhile linked by intel towards their own term [[Omni-Path Architecture]] (OPA) in publications.[https://www.intel.de/content/www/de/de/high-performance-computing-fabrics/omni-path-driving-exascale-computing.html Intel® Omni-Path Architecture (Intel® OPA) Driving Exascale Computing and HPC; Driving Exascale Computing and HPC with Intel], intel publication without a date ==={{anchor|Knights Mill}}Knights Mill=== Knights Mill is Intel's codename for a Xeon Phi product specialized in [[deep learning]],{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Ryan|title=Intel Announces Knight's Mill: A Xeon Phi for Deep Learning|url=https://www.anandtech.com/show/10575/intel-announces-knights-mill-a-xeon-phi-for-deep-learning|accessdate=17 August 2016|publisher=Anandtech|date=17 August 2016}} initially released in December 2017.{{cite news|last1=Cutress|first1=Ian|title=Intel Lists Knights Mill Xeon Phi on ARK: Up to 72 cores at 320W with QFMA and VNNI|url=https://www.anandtech.com/show/12172/intel-lists-knights-mill-xeon-phi-on-ark-up-to-72-cores-at-320w-with-qfma-and-vnni|accessdate=19 December 2017|publisher=Anandtech|date=19 December 2017}} Nearly identical in specifications to Knights Landing, Knights Mill includes optimizations for better utilization of AVX-512 instructions and enables 4-way [[Hyperthreading|hyperthreading]]. {{Infobox company | name = Envestnet Yodlee | logo = ENV Yodlee Color Logo RGB.jpg | logo_size = 200px | logo_alt = Yodlee logo | type = | industry = [[Financial]] | predecessor = | successor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1999}} | founder = [[Venkat Rangan]] | hq_location_city = [[Redwood City, California]] | key_people = Anil Arora
{{small|(CEO)}} | products = }} '''Yodlee''' is an American software company that develops an [[account aggregation]] service that allows users to see their credit card, bank, investment, email, travel reward accounts, etc. on one screen. In addition, '''Yodlee Labs''' (formerly Yodlee MoneyCenter), a free web application that helps consumers with their finances online, provides features such as bill payment, expense tracking, and investment management (similar to personal finance services provided by Intuit's [[Quicken]]). Yodlee's Privacy Policy FAQ references Yodlee as a licensee of the TRUSTe Privacy Program.{{cite press release | title=Yodlee Privacy FAQ|url=http://corporate.yodlee.com/ymc_privacy.shtml}}. Part of Yodlee's business model consists of selling its customer's financial transaction data to investors. {{cite news |last=Hope |first=Bradley |date=2015-08-06 |title=Provider of Personal Finance Tools Tracks Bank Cards, Sells Data to Investors |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/provider-of-personal-finance-tools-tracks-bank-cards-sells-data-to-investors-1438914620 |work=Wall Street Journal |access-date=2017-05-22}} In August 2015, '''[http://www.envestnet.com/press/envestnet-completes-acquisition-yodlee Envestnet]''' acquired '''Yodlee'''. As of 2013, Yodlee has over 45 million users, and over 150 financial institutions and portals (including 5 of the top 10 U.S. banks) offer services powered by Yodlee.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/07/06/with-top-banks-in-tow-financial-service-provider-yodlee-hits-30-million-users/ |title = With Top Banks In Tow, Financial Service Provider Yodlee Hits 30 Million Users.|author=TechCrunch}}{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/09/18/mint-is-yodlees-youtube|title=Mint Is Yodlee's YouTube|author=TechCrunch}} Yodlee's aggregation engine powers several applications for partners, including websites like [[Money_dashboard|Money Dashboard]], [[Strands|MoneyStrand]], [[Thrive (website)|Thrive]], and several large banks and financial institutions. In 2010, Yodlee partnered with [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]], providing its financial services platforms to all Y Combinator-funded companies.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/11/30/y-combinator-and-yodlee-team-up-to-give-startups-access-to-financial-data|title=Y Combinator and Yodlee Team-up To Give Startups Access To Financial Data|author=TechCrunch}} ==Origins and history== Yodlee was started since 1999 by [[Venkat Rangan]] (vice chancellor of Amrita University); Sam Inala, Ramakrishna "Schwark" Satyavolu, Srihari Sampath Kumar (all earlier at Microsoft); and [[Sukhinder_Singh_Cassidy|Sukhinder Singh]] (earlier at Amazon.com and Junglee).{{cite press release|title=Yodleeing Their Way to the Top| url=http://www.rediff.com/news/1999/oct/30us2.htm}} Yodlee started operations (and is headquartered) in [[Redwood Shores, California]]. It also has offices in London, UK, and Bangalore, India. In 2000, Yodlee merged with its main competitor in the data aggregation space, an Atlanta-based company called VerticalOne, which was owned at the time by SecurityFirst, an internet banking firm.{{cite web|title=S1 Corporation Completes Acquisition of VerticalOne Corporation|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/s1-corporation-completes-acquisition-of-verticalone-corporation-77138602.html|website=prnewswire.com|date=November 11, 1999|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=25 March 2017}}{{cite web|title=Company Overview of VerticalOne Corporation|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=36239|website=bloomberg.com|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=25 March 2017}} By 2010 Yodlee was said to have raised at least $116 million over its 10-year lifespan.{{cite web |url = https://techcrunch.com/2009/09/18/mint-is-yodlees-youtube|title =Mint Is Yodlee's YouTube.|author=TechCrunch}} In a press release in June 2008, it was announced that Bank of America led a $35 million financing and existing Yodlee investors, including its largest shareholder [[Warburg Pincus]] along with [[Accel Partners]] and [[Institutional Venture Partners]] participated in the financing round.{{cite web|url=http://www.finextra.com/fullstory.asp?id=18546|title=Yodlee raises $35m funding}} On October 3, 2014, Yodlee went public on NASDAQ, trading under the symbol YDLE. It raised $75 million at $12/share.{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com//2014/10/02/yodlee-a-hub-for-financial-apps-raises-75-million-in-i-p-o/ |title =Yodlee, a Hub for Financial apps, Raises $75 Million in IPO|author=New York Times}} On August 10, 2015 Yodlee sold itself to [[Envestnet]] for a reported $660 Million.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/11/business/dealbook/yodlee-a-hub-for-financial-apps-sells-itself-to-envestnet.html|title=Yodlee, a Hub for Financial Apps, Sells Itself to Envestnet|author=New York Times}} As a result, it is no longer listed on the NASDAQ. In November 2017 Token partnered with Yodlee for payments and financial data aggregation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/1064352/token-and-envestnet-yodlee-team-up-for-open-banking/|title=Token and Envestnet {{!}} Yodlee team up for open banking » Banking Technology|website=www.bankingtech.com|access-date=2017-11-14}} ==References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == *{{Crunchbase}} [[Category:Financial services companies of the United States]] [[Category:Financial technology companies]] [[Category:Account aggregation providers]] [[Category:Companies based in Redwood Shores, California]] [[Category:Private equity portfolio companies]] [[Category:Warburg Pincus companies]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on NASDAQ]]
